Q0.reasoning: Patient information explicitly states Whole Genome Sequencing (WGS) is being requested.

Q1.reasoning: Policy specifies age-based criteria for pediatric evaluation (<18 years) for genome/exome sequencing; the patient is 9 years old, meeting the age criterion (policy Section II.1: "individuals less than 18 years of age").

Q2.reasoning: Policy requires evaluation/counseling by an ABMGG board-certified medical geneticist or an ABGC board-certified genetic counselor (Section II.1.a). The chart states a "pre-test discussion with a genetic specialist" but does not document the provider's ABMGG/ABGC certification, so sufficiency cannot be confirmed from the provided information.

Q3.reasoning: Policy allows WGS only when WES was unable to identify a causative mutation and clinical suspicion remains (Section II.4). The patient has not had WES per the provided information, so the policy-defined medical indication for WGS is not met.

Q4.reasoning: Policy requires WES (and/or prior tests) before WGS when clinical criteria apply (Section II.4 and II.5). The patient has had fragile X testing but has not had WES; therefore the required prior test (WES) before WGS has not been completed.

Q5.reasoning: The policy does not list family history/consanguinity as a specific mandatory eligibility criterion for pediatric WGS in Section II.1; although the patient has a maternal uncle with an immunologic disorder, the policy's core WGS/WES pediatric criteria do not hinge on this family history.

Q6.reasoning: Policy requires pre-test counseling by an ABMGG board-certified medical geneticist or an ABGC board-certified genetic counselor (Section II.1.a). The record notes a pre-test discussion with a "genetic specialist" but does not document the required ABMGG/ABGC credentialing or that counseling covered the required elements, so this cannot be confirmed.

Q7.reasoning: The requested test is Whole Genome Sequencing (WGS); CPT code 81425 corresponds to WGS (best match for the requested whole-genome test).

Q8.reasoning: Per policy, WGS MEETS COVERAGE CRITERIA only when WES was performed and unable to identify a causative mutation and clinical suspicion persists (Section II.4). The patient has not had WES (only fragile X testing), and required prior testing/sequence pathway has not been satisfied; therefore WGS is not covered under the policy for this request.
